problems.title: Blackboard Game
problems.statementHtml:
Initially, the integers from 00 to n−1n−1 are written on a blackboard.

In one round,

Rounds take place in succession until a player is unable to make a move — the first player who is unable to make a move loses. Determine who wins with optimal play.

∗∗We define that x≡y(modm)x≡y(modm) whenever x−yx−y is an integer multiple of mm.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100) — the number of integers written on the blackboard.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Alice" if Alice wins with optimal play, and "Bob" if Bob wins with optimal play.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "aLiCe", "alice", "ALICE", and "alICE" will be recognized as "Alice".
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample, suppose Alice chooses 00, then Bob cannot choose any number so Alice wins immediately.

In the second sample, suppose Alice chooses 00, then Bob can choose 33. Then suppose Alice chooses 22, then Bob can choose 11. Then Alice has no numbers remaining, so Bob wins.

problems.title: Tournament
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array of integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. A tournament is held with nn players. Player ii has strength aiai.

While more than kk players remain,

Given integers jj and kk (1≤j,k≤n1≤j,k≤n), determine if there is any way for player jj to be one of the last kk remaining players.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, jj, and kk (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤j,k≤n1≤j,k≤n).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "YES" if player jj can be one of the last kk remaining players, and "NO" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample, suppose that players 22 and 55 are chosen. Then player 22 defeats player 55. Now, the remaining player strengths are

3244
Next, suppose that players 33 and 44 are chosen. Then player 33 might defeat player 44. Now, the remaining player strengths are
324
Player 22 is one of the last three players remaining.

In the third sample, it can be shown that there is no way for player 11 to be the last player remaining.

problems.title: Prefix Min and Suffix Max
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array aa of distinct integers.

In one operation, you may either:

Note that you may choose the entire array aa.

For each element aiai, determine if there exists some sequence of operations to transform aa into [ai][ai]; that is, make the array aa consist of only one element, which is aiai. Output your answer as a binary string of length nn, where the ii-th character is 11 if there exists a sequence to transform aa into [ai][ai], and 00 otherwise.

∗∗A prefix of an array is a subarray consisting of the first kk elements of the array, for some integer kk.

††A suffix of an array is a subarray consisting of the last kk elements of the array, for some integer kk.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the size of the array aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1061≤ai≤106). It is guaranteed that all aiai are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a binary string of length nn  — the ii-th character should be 11 if there exists a sequence of operations as described above, and 00 otherwise.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample, you can first choose the prefix of size 33. Then the array is transformed into

1472
Next, you can choose the suffix of size 22. Then the array is transformed into
147
Finally, you can choose the prefix of size 33. Then the array is transformed into
1
So we see that it is possible to transform aa into [1][1].

It can be shown that it is impossible to transform aa into [3][3].

problems.title: Binary String Battle
problems.statementHtml:
Alice and Bob are given a binary string ss of length nn, and an integer kk (1≤k<n1≤k<n).

Alice wins if she is able to transform all characters of ss into zeroes. If Alice is unable to win in a finite number of moves, then Bob wins.

Alice and Bob take turns, with Alice going first.

Note that Alice wins if the string consists of all zeros at any point during the game, including in between Alice's and Bob's turns.

Determine who wins with optimal play.

∗∗A subsequence of a string ss is a set of characters in ss. Note that these characters do not have to be adjacent.

††A substring of a string ss is a contiguous group of characters in ss. Note that these characters must be adjacent.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤k<n1≤k<n).

The second line of each test case contains a binary string ss of length nn.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Alice" if Alice wins with optimal play, and "Bob" if Bob wins with optimal play.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "aLiCe", "alice", "ALICE", and "alICE" will be recognized as "Alice".
problems.noteHtml:
In the third sample, Alice can choose the subsequence consisting of s2s2, turning ss into 000000000000. Then she wins immediately.

In the fourth sample, it can be shown that there is no way for Alice to guarantee that she can turn ss into 00000000 within a finite number of moves.

samples.output:
Bob
Alice
Alice
Bob
Bob
Alice

problems.title: MEX Count
problems.statementHtml:
Define the MEX (minimum excluded value) of an array to be the smallest nonnegative integer not present in the array. For example,

You are given an array a of size n of nonnegative integers.

For all k (0≤k≤n), count the number of possible values of MEX(a) after removing exactly k values from a.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer t (1≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains one integer n (1≤n≤2⋅105) — the size of the array a.

The second line of each test case contains n integers, a1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single line containing n+1 integers — the number of possible values of MEX(a) after removing exactly k values, for k=0,1,…,n.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample, consider k=1. If you remove a 0, then you get the following array:

1012
So we get MEX(a)=3. Alternatively, if you remove the 2, then you get the following array:
1001
So we get MEX(a)=2. It can be shown that these are the only possible values of MEX(a) after removing exactly one value. So the output for k=1 is 2.

problems.title: Minimize Fixed Points
problems.statementHtml:
Call a permutation∗ p of length n good if gcd(pi,i)† >1 for all 2≤i≤n. Find a good permutation with the minimum number of fixed points‡ across all good permutations of length n. If there are multiple such permutations, print any of them.

∗ A permutation of length n is an array that contains every integer from 1 to n exactly once, in any order.

†gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of x and y.

‡A fixed point of a permutation p is an index j (1≤j≤n) such that pj=j.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer t (1≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains an integer n (2≤n≤105) — the length of the permutation.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output on a single line an example of a good permutation of length n with the minimum number of fixed points.
problems.noteHtml:
In the third sample, we construct the permutation

ipigcd(pi,i)
111
242
363
422
555
633
Then we see that gcd(pi,i)>1 for all 2≤i≤6. Furthermore, we see that there are only two fixed points, namely, 1 and 5. It can be shown that it is impossible to build a good permutation of length 6 with fewer fixed points.

problems.title: Modular Sorting
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an integer mm (2≤m≤5⋅1052≤m≤5⋅105) and an array aa consisting of nonnegative integers smaller than mm.

Answer queries of the following form:

Note that instances of query 22 are independent; that is, no actual operations are taking place. Instances of query 11 are persistent.

∗∗a(modm)a(modm) is defined as the unique integer bb such that 0≤b<m0≤b<m and a−ba−b is an integer multiple of mm.

††An array aa of size nn is called nondecreasing if and only if ai≤ai+1ai≤ai+1 for all 1≤i<n1≤i<n.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains three integers, nn, mm, and qq (2≤n≤1052≤n≤105, 2≤m≤5⋅1052≤m≤5⋅105, 1≤q≤1051≤q≤105) — the size of the array aa, the integer mm, and the number of queries.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai<m0≤ai<m).

Then follows qq lines. Each line is of one of the following forms:

  • 11 ii xx (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, 0≤x<m0≤x<m)
  • 22 kk (1≤k<m1≤k<m)

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn and the sum of qq over all test cases each do not exceed 105105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each instance of query 22, output on a single line "YES" if there exists some sequence of (possibly zero) operations to make aa nondecreasing, and "NO" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample, the array is initially:

4522410

By applying the operation twice on a1a1, twice on a2a2, once on a5a5, twice on a6a6, and once on a7a7, the array becomes:

0122234
which is in nondecreasing order.

After the second query, the array becomes:

4525410
and it can be shown that it is impossible to sort this with operations of the form ai:=(ai+4)(mod6)ai:=(ai+4)(mod6), and it is also impossible to sort this with operations of the form ai:=(ai+3)(mod6)ai:=(ai+3)(mod6).

samples.output:
YES
NO
NO
YES
YES
NO
